name: Penang George Town
fun_fact: Fun fact: George Town is ranked #39 on TasteAtlas's list of the 100 Best Food Regions in the World, and locals are so serious about their char kway teow that debates about which stall makes the best version can last for hours - some say it's worth the trip to Penang for this single dish alone.

hero_dishes.name: Char Kway Teow
hero_dishes.description: Flat rice noodles stir-fried over intense heat with prawns, cockles, Chinese sausage, eggs, bean sprouts, and chives in dark soy sauce
hero_dishes.origin_story: Most people agree you find the best char kway teow in Penang. The key is the 'wok hei' (breath of the wok) - that smoky flavor from cooking over extremely high heat. At Ah Leng, they make it with duck eggs for an even richer, creamier texture
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Ah Leng Char Koay Teow (duck egg version for RM12.50), numerous hawker stalls throughout George Town

hero_dishes.name: Penang Assam Laksa
hero_dishes.description: Spicy and tangy fish-based noodle soup made with mackerel and tamarind juice, garnished with fresh mint, pineapple, and torch ginger flower
hero_dishes.origin_story: This is Penang's most iconic dish - so beloved that it's ranked among the world's best soups. The tamarind gives it a mouth-puckering sourness that's addictive
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Joo Hooi Cafe (popular spot, RM5 per bowl)

hero_dishes.name: Nasi Kandar
hero_dishes.description: Steamed rice served with a variety of curries and side dishes - the name comes from the kandar (pole) used to carry rice and curry by street vendors
hero_dishes.origin_story: Hameediyah restaurant has been serving nasi kandar since 1907, making it Malaysia's oldest nasi kandar joint. The recipe has been passed down through generations
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Hameediyah (open since 1907 - Malaysia's oldest), numerous 24-hour nasi kandar shops

hero_dishes.name: Nyonya/Peranakan Cuisine
hero_dishes.description: Unique fusion of Chinese and Malay cooking created by the Straits-Chinese Peranakan community - complex spice pastes and rich coconut-based dishes
hero_dishes.origin_story: When Chinese immigrants married local Malay women centuries ago, they created a unique cuisine. Auntie Gaik Lean's Old School Eatery serves traditional Peranakan dishes exactly as they were made generations ago
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Auntie Gaik Lean's Old School Eatery (Michelin-recognized), Ivy's Nyonya Cuisine

signature_drinks.name: Cendol
signature_drinks.description: Sweet dessert drink with green pandan jelly noodles, red beans, shaved ice, and coconut milk drizzled with palm sugar syrup
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Consumed as a cooling treat in Penang's tropical heat, especially in the afternoon. The contrast of ice-cold sweetness with chewy green jelly is irresistible

signature_drinks.name: Teh Tarik
signature_drinks.description: Pulled tea - strong black tea with condensed milk, poured back and forth between cups to create a frothy head
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: At mamak stalls and kopitiams (coffee shops) throughout the day. The 'pulling' cools the tea and creates a signature froth on top

food_culture_notes: George Town is the food capital of Southeast Asia with Malay, Chinese, Indian, and Peranakan influences
Hawker centers are the heart of Penang food culture - Chulia Street and Padang Brown are legendary
Hot Bowl White Curry Mee on Jalan Rangoon is featured in the Michelin guide
Plan at least 3 days to explore the UNESCO World Heritage area and its food scene
